text: I wouldn't know what it's like to hit a
dead end every project I've ever worked
on ends up ahead of schedule and under
budget we always get it right the first
time and we ship it and it's always
perfect but I could imagine that there
are other people that don't have that
situation um
actually nothing could be further from
the
truth every project we've ever done
without exception you start out with
some simple objective it always seems
simple and then you get into the ugly
reality of trying to accomplish that
simple
objective
and nature is
it's it's not cruel but it's very
subtle and
inevitably you're surprised along the
way as you try to make things happen and
almost all the surprises are bad
surprises new problems keep cropping up
things that seem like they should work
don't a simple elegant
idea turns out to have a bunch of ugly
facts related to that elegant idea and
no matter how elegant the idea is the
facts win so you you rethink that idea
you try different strategies you employ
different
Technologies and as you said in the end
if it finally
Works people think you started with this
idea you went on a straight line and
concluded with this product and in fact
they not only think that but the way
media present it it reinforces that
because media has a finite amount of
time to tell a story media has a finite
attention span nobody wants to hear
literally the five years of frustration
that you took taking all the wrong paths
for one thing no matter how fast you'd
speak if they ask you about this project
that took you five years if they really
wanted the truth the whole truth and
nothing but the truth it would take you
five years to tell it you'd have to tell
all the crazy places you got on a piece
of spaghetti and you ran through every
strand of spaghetti in that bowl until
you got to the end they don't want to
know all about that spaghetti they want
to know where you started and as quickly
as they can they want to know the result
and how it can affect them so we all As
a matter of course when asked about how
we do anything in our lives we start
with some big thought we might tell a
few of the funny incidental side paths
but then in a finite amount of time an
interview a book we get to the
conclusion people want at best with a
couple of references to uh a little side
path here or there as a consequence of
all of that people begin to think that
oh some
inventor in fact really starts with a
big idea runs along a line gets to the
conclusion ships it off and starts the
next idea when in fact at least in my
case you jumped in the spaghetti Bowl
you crawled over every strand in that
bowl some of them you'll swear you
covered at least five times and then if
you finally ever emerge at the other end
where you want it to be which does
sometimes happen but it's rare instantly
you forget about all that spaghetti in
the bull you bask for a moment in the
victory of getting where you want it to
be the story gets told as a little quip
and you move on and the great the great
myth that it was a straight line is
unintentionally I think supported by
that event the most consistent
characteristic I've ever seen of people
that
succeed is that they never give up they
work and they work and they work and
they fail not once in a while but they
fail way way way more often than most
people fail because they are trying to
do something that other people haven't
done yet and when you try to do
something that hasn't been done when you
haven't been given the road map because
no road map exists yet you're obvious ly
going to make more mistakes and take
more wrong turns than anybody that likes
to travel with a map so those people
that go out and try to do new and
different things fail way more often
than the people that don't it doesn't
matter however because once they succeed
they hand all of us the map and then we
enjoy the benefits of all their failures
and they move on to trying to solve the
next
problem
